Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Validation of newly uploaded packages" (#167) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Smoke test newly uploaded packages to ensure packages meet basic standards.

This also increases overall package quality on the gallery and mitigates risks such as defined in http://nuget.codeplex.com/workitem/1686

Maybe add some recommendations as well? (e.g. your package seems to be larger than average, consider splitting your package into multiple ones with proper dependencies if individual components can be used without requiring the full package contents)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Include richer statistics for package downloads" (#4808) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently we can get number of downloads per package and how they were downloaded. But there is more that could be included that will help developers measure different metrics. 

For example, how many are updates from an earlier version and how many are new installs to an existing or new project. What about distinguishing between a download that has been initiated by the user vs a download that has been pulled down because it is a dependency on another nuget (bonus for what nuget). 

This data in addition to the existing statistics van help interpolate any data we would need.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.Server 2.14.0 does not show Published package property in Visual Studio UI" (#4689) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
_**Copied from https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Server/pull/23, on behalf of @sean-rose.**_

@joelverhagen  I've run into a problem:  I was particularly interested in getting the published date fix, but now in my testing no published date is being shown at all for packages when browsing via Visual Studio (tested in VS 2013, VS 2015, and VS 2017).

Looking through the history, I believe the cause is in commit 9a2dd68 the following attribute was added to the `ODataPackage` class:

```C#
    [EntityPropertyMapping("Published", SyndicationItemProperty.Published, SyndicationTextContentKind.Plaintext, keepInContent: false)]
```

I'd be happy to submit a pull request to change that to `keepInContent: true` but I'm not familiar enough with the reason for adding the attribute in the first place to know what else that might affect.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Latest Version on Manage Packages does not show SemVer 2.0.0 packages" (#4796) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: fixes #4782

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Hard delete of package doesn't delete package owner requests" (#4807) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Repo:
- Create package
- Add new owner to the package
- Hard delete the package through the Admin panel
- Go to Account->Manage Packages

You'll see 500 server error due to NullReferenceException in OwnerRequestsListItemViewModel. The cause is that the PackageOwnerRequest still exists in the DB, but the PackageRegistration was deleted.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Cancel of package upload relies on parser error to clear the page" (#4806) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Repo:
- Open the Upload page
- F12, add breakpoint at async-file-upload->handleErrors (line 165)
- Upload a package, which sends POST to /packages/manage/cancel-upload
- Breakpoint in handleErrors should be hit

resultCodeString = "parsererror".

Stack is:
    "SyntaxError: Unexpected end of JSON input
    at JSON.parse (<anonymous>)
    at jQuery.parseJSON (https://localhost/Scripts/gallery/jquery-1.12.4.js:9011:22)
    at ajaxConvert (https://localhost/Scripts/gallery/jquery-1.12.4.js:9335:19)
    at done (https://localhost/Scripts/gallery/jquery-1.12.4.js:9789:15)
    at XMLHttpRequest.callback (https://localhost/Scripts/gallery/jquery-1.12.4.js:10311:8)"

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Upload fails due to model binding error" (#4804) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
On DEV environment, you can't upload a package due to an error in the page-edit-readme model binding. Works in INT/PROD.

The issue is that bindModel is getting passed an empty string, where as it should be passed null on the first callback. This breaks in readme model binding which relies on an observable property on the model to detect tab selection.

Also seen by @cristinamanum

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Assets from packages are missing after restore" (#5995) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Some users have reported that after restoring assets such as System.Runtime are missing from the assets file.

This is potentially caused by restore happening while the fallback folder is still being created. The problem is made much worse by how restore reuses file lists from previous restores for the next restore. To improve this experience restore should read the files from disk each time instead of from the previous assets file.

Note that if the fallback folder from the CLI is corrupt then this should be fixed there also.

See: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/920

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet Pack modifies the escape character to escape code in file path" (#5994) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
While packing a NuGet package, file path is being updated to have escape code instead of actual character in output nupkg.

Steps:
1. Take this sample solution https://github.com/NuGet/Samples/tree/master/ContentFilesExample/authoring 
2. With latest NuGet.exe, run `nuget pack ContentFilesExample.nuspec -Exclude pack.ps1`

Expected:
.nupkg has `ContentFilesExample.1.0.0.nupkg\contentFiles\cs\portable-net45+wpa81+wp8+win8\`

Actual:
.nupkg had `ContentFilesExample.1.0.0.nupkg\contentFiles\cs\portable-net45%2Bwpa81%2Bwp8%2Bwin8\`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package versions not ordered correctly when using full semver 2.0" (#5993) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
VS Feedback Item - 

I'm having the problem with sorting in "manage package for solution page", but also in automatic references upgrading of packages within the projects. I have this 2 packages in my repository:
0.0.0-branchname.10
0.0.0-branchname.9
but 0.0.0-branchname.9 is considered as latest, which is wrong obviouslyI think last number is not taken as number but as string which I think is wrong basic on semantic versioning specification


Hello, I'm using our packages generated within jenkins pipeline, we always put branchname as branchname in the example from gitlab, but I believe there is as problem after last dot, it seems to me like it is considered as string, but it's number based on semver2 spec. But I took a quick look in public nuget repo a there are no packages numbered like this. For example package "Microsoft.AspNetCore.Routing" has prerelease version 2.1.0-preview1-27020 but I need to have like this 2.1.0-preview1-27020.1, this should be completely fine if we are talking about semver2 support, so the last number after last dot is not ordered as number but as string and that's wrong

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget push can't handle paths with forward slash on windows" (#5992) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @wojciechrak on October 5, 2017 13:56_

## Steps to reproduce
`nuget push C:\dev/nugets\*.nupkg`

## Expected  behavior
All packages in directory C:\dev\nugets are pushed to nuget repository.

## Actual behavior
Error is returned
`File does not exist (c:\dev/nugets\*.nupkg).`

## Additional notes
`nuget pack -OutputDirectory C:\dev/nugets\` or `nuget pack solutiondir/projectdir/project.csproj` work correctly
I am using standalone nuget.exe
NuGet Version: 4.3.0.4406

## Issue background
In our CI we are fetching feature branches from git and path on disk contains branch name, eg. "feature/123". This branch name is then used in our build scripts.








_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#7764_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Markdown based documentation for packages" (#9) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Package-README.md-support|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2280|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).
